There's nothing I can say about this game that hasn't been said in the 8 years that it's been out. It has pretty much everything one has come to expect in a Valve Single-player game; awesome level-designs, great music, quirky humor, etc. If you haven't played this game yet, do give it a try, it won't disappoint. Even if it does (probably won't), it's just $5.

구멍 2.

클리어까지 고작 2시간이면 충분했던 포탈의 팬들을 위한 밸브의 선물. 더욱 다양해진 실험실들, 여기저기 숨어있는 힌트들과 비밀, 감자, 그리고 두 번째 통수까지. 출시하고 꽤 오랜 시간이 흘렀으나 스팀 유저라면 꼭 한번 해보고 죽어야 하는 명작중의 명작,
Juego de inteligencia, paciencia, destreza, trabajo en equipo, bastante entretenido en modo campaña y un sin fin de niveles que hace la comunidad del juego.

As someone who generally sucks at using their brain to solve puzzles in video games, I was initially hesitant to purchase this game, but my friend promised it would be worth my time and money to play it with him, so I threw caution to the wind. Having now completed both the single-player story mode and co-op mode, I am glad that I gave this game a chance. Granted, the further you get in this game, the harder the puzzles become, but that "a-ha!" moment you get when you figure out what to do, do it, and then pass the level is incredibly rewarding. If you're worried that you'll get bored of the game solving puzzle after puzzle after puzzle, fear not, because the humor in this game is outstanding. Half the time I just wanted to solve the puzzle just to hear what smart or quick remark my robot companions had to say about it. Overall, I would recommend that you give Portal 2 a shot if you haven't already, and try to play with a friend if at all possible in the co-op mode, as I had an absolute blast messing around with my friend as I continued to screw things up for us.

Portal 2 is one of the best puzzle games I’ve ever played. The core gameplay has you placing down portals to move. You can place down no more than two portals at once and portals can transport you and some moveable objects. The portals can be placed on some areas and not on others. While the possibilities may seem limited with this gimmick at first, Valve does plenty to make the mechanic work. The game has a lot of different items which can be used to complete different puzzles. These items can be transported through portals. Some items include boxes which can be placed on top of buttons to unlock hidden areas or gel which can make you jump higher than you can normally. The rooms all have different arrangements. There are different obstacles in your way such as water which will drown you or turrets which will fire at you. The portal feature allows for you to traverse through the levels easily and pull off some insane tricks, whether that be going onto a jump pad that boosts your jump tenfold, and then have yourself boosted through a portal across the map or shoot gel at walls so you can bounce off them. New gameplay mechanics are introduced very swiftly so you never become bored of the levels. The scenery of Portal is nice. It’s mostly simple white and grey walls inside a testing facility, aside from when you occasionally get away from the testing chamber to a factory or something along those lines. The story is phenomenal, too. While at first it seems like a simple story that’s a continuation of the last story, you have to defeat GLaDOS, who escaped her chamber as the facility is being destroyed, to escape the facility and leave for good. Despite the fact that it may seem like a simple story of the protagonist defeating the big villain to return home, the story is filled with twists and turns and ends with one of video gaming's best bosses ever. The characters are all fabulous too. The genius of the game is that there’s only three main characters: Chell who returns from the previous game. Chell is sort of a blank slate for you to portray yourself and your emotions onto but she still has some character. Wheatley is an energetic, zany, and outgoing robot who tries to help Chell with her adventure home and, finally, there’s GLaDOS, the main villain of the story, or so it seems at first glance. While I don’t want to spoil the story, GLaDOS is essential to the game’s biggest plot twists and evolves into a much more complex character as the story goes on. The simplicity of this triangle dynamic is the real genius of the game's characters. Overall, I feel like Portal 2 is a phenomenal experience that every gamer should experience and I still struggle to find anything wrong with it.

Score: 10/10
